content.description: The figures above show a small block of mass <math alttext="0.20 kilogram" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on a track in the shape of a circular arc. The block is released from rest at a height <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the floor, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block slides along the track with negligible friction and leaves it at a height of <math alttext="0.40 meter" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.40</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> above the floor and a speed of <math alttext="3.0 meters per second" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at a <math alttext="30 degrees" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi>Â°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> angle, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
